description.title: Moon Geocentric Position
description.what: Computes geocentric RA/Dec of the Moon. Note: ERFA/Astropy use simplified Meeus (~10 arcmin accuracy) while Siderust/libnova use full ELP 2000.
description.why: Moon position accuracy varies significantly between libraries because no standard 'reference' implementation exists in ERFA.
description.units: Angular separation in arcseconds. Expect ~arcminute differences due to model gap.
description.interpret: Large differences (arcminutes) reflect different ephemeris models, not bugs. Cross-library comparison is more meaningful than ERFA-as-truth here.

alignment.time_input: JD (Julian Date), TT scale for precession/nutation, UT1 for sidereal time
alignment.time_scales: TT for BPN matrix; UT1≈TT-69.184s simplified
alignment.leap_seconds: not applicable (JD input, no UTC conversion in this experiment)

library_notes.astropy: The 'astropy' adapter calls ERFA/pyerfa C kernels directly from Python. Accuracy results are identical to ERFA. Performance results measure Python-loop + ERFA-kernel overhead, NOT the high-level astropy.coordinates stack.

models.erfa: Simplified Meeus Ch.47 (major terms only, ~10' accuracy)
models.siderust: Simplified Meeus Ch.47 (major terms only), centralized in siderust astro module
models.astropy: Simplified Meeus Ch.47 (same algorithm as ERFA adapter)
models.anise: SPK translation MOON_J2000 → EARTH_J2000 (DE440 ephemeris, geometric state vector)

alignment.accuracy_interpretation: agreement with ERFA baseline (ERFA uses simplified Meeus, libnova uses full ELP 2000 — arcminute-level differences are expected)
alignment.note: ERFA, Astropy, and Siderust use the same simplified Meeus benchmark model (~10' accuracy). libnova uses full ELP 2000, so arcminute-level differences vs reference are expected. No dedicated ERFA Moon ephemeris exists; cross-library comparison is the primary metric.
